Fig. 1 Methanol productivity based on (a) catalyst weight and (b) Cu weight in yCu/CeO2 catalyst (y =5, 10 and 20wt.%): reaction pressure 3MPa; reaction temperature 190–270°C; catalyst weight 0.2g; feed stream flow 10mL/min; feed composition: 22vol.% CO2; 66vol.% H2; 12vol.% N2; H2/CO2 =3. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Methanol productivity based on (a) catalyst weight and (b) Cu weight in xPd–10Cu/CeO2 catalyst (x =0, 0.5, 1, 2wt.%): reaction pressure 3MPa; reaction temperature 190–270°C; catalyst weight 0.2g; feed stream flow 10mL/min; feed composition: 22vol.% CO2; 66vol.% H2; 12vol.% N2; H2/CO2 =3. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Methanol productivity based on Pd weight in xPd–10Cu/CeO2 catalyst (x =0, 0.5, 1, 2wt.%): reaction pressure 3MPa; reaction temperature 190–270°C; catalyst weight 0.2g; feed stream flow 10mL/min; feed composition: 22vol.% CO2; 66vol.% H2; 12vol.% N2; H2/CO2 =3. Hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol over Pd–Cu/CeO2 catalysts Eun Jeong Choi a 1 Yong Hee Lee a 1 Dae-Won Lee b Dong-Ju Moon c Kwan-Young Lee a d ⁎ a Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Korea University, Anam-dong, Seongbuk-gu, Seoul 02841, Republic of Korea Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Korea University Anam-dong Seongbuk-gu, Seoul 02841 Republic of Korea b Department of Chemical Engineering, Kangwon National University, 1 Kangwondaehak-gil, Chuncheon-si, Gangwon-do 24341, Republic of Korea Department of Chemical Engineering, Kangwon National University 1 Kangwondaehak-gil Chuncheon-si, Gangwon-do 24341 Republic of Korea c Clean Energy Research Center, Korea Institute of Science and Technology, Seoul, Republic of Korea Clean Energy Research Center, Korea Institute of Science and Technology Seoul Republic of Korea d KU-KIST School of Converging Science and Technology, Korea University, Anam-dong, Seongbuk-gu, Seoul 02841, Republic of Korea KU-KIST School of Converging Science and Technology, Korea University Anam-dong Seongbuk-gu, Seoul 02841 Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding author at: Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Korea University, Anam-dong, Seongbuk-gu, Seoul 02841, Republic of Korea. 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. Graphical abstract CO2 hydrogenation to methanol receives great attention recently not only in conventional CO hydrogenation process but also in CO2 and H2 storage technologies. CO2 can be converted to methanol by catalytic hydrogenation, and it is supposed that CO2 is hydrogenated to methanol via hydrocarboxyl (COOH) intermediate (rWGSR route) rather than formate (HCOO) intermediate. It was reported that CeOx/Cu(111) surface stabilizes COOH intermediate, which consecutively results in lower activation energy for methanol formation than on Cu(111) and Cu / ZnO ( 000 1 ¯ ) surfaces. The activity of Cu/CeO2 catalysts can be further enhanced by Pd addition, because it can enhance reducibility of Cu site. In this study, therefore, Cu/CeO2 and Pd–Cu/CeO2 catalysts were applied to CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. Pd-promoted Cu/CeO2 catalysts achieved higher methanol productivity than Cu/CeO2 catalyst due to the increase in CO2 conversion. Because methanol productivity over Pd weight (mmolMeOH/gPd·h) simply decreased as the amount of Pd increased, it is considered that the enhanced activity of Pd–Cu/CeO2 catalysts mainly resulted from the increase in the reactivity of active Cu sites. The dispersion and surface concentration of Cu increased due to the interaction with highly-dispersed Pd, and Cu sites were more reduced by Pd promotion due to electron donation from Pd. Pd promotion also generated more reduced CeO2 surface. These promoting effects of Pd was the highest in the catalyst containing 1wt.% Pd (1Pd–10Cu/CeO2), because further increase in the amount of loaded Pd lowered the textural properties of catalyst. As a result, methanol productivity was enhanced in Pd-promoted Cu/CeO2 catalysts and the highest in 1Pd–10Cu/CeO2 catalyst. Keywords Methanol CO2 hydrogenation Cu/CeO2 catalyst Pd–Cu/CeO2 catalyst 1 Introduction Methanol (CH3OH) is widely used as a solvent, alternative fuel, and intermediate chemical for producing valuable petrochemicals. As a fuel, the forte for methanol is its liquid state in atmospheric conditions (25°C, 0.1MPa), which makes it easy to transport and store. Therefore, methanol can be simply blended with other conventional liquid fuels such as gasoline and diesel [1]. Also, because methanol is one of the most important hydrogen storage materials, it can be used as a hydrogen supplier in direct methanol fuel cell (DMFC) [2,3]. On the other hand, methanol is one of the most important starting-materials for the synthesis of valuable chemicals and fuels [1,4]. It can be converted to formaldehyde (H2CO), acetic acid (CH3COOH), dimethyl ether (DME, CH3OCH3), methyl tert-butyl ether (MTBE), olefins (methanol-to-olefin, MTO), gasoline (methanol-to-gasoline, MTG), etc. [5] As a result, the demand for methanol is estimated to increase continuously in this decade (from 59.5 million metric tons in 2013 to 106 million metric tons in 2023) [5,6]. Methanol is industrially produced from synthesis gas (the mixture gas of H2 and CO). Although coal or biomass are often used as the carbon sources for producing synthesis gas, natural gas is the most common carbon source in methanol synthesis process. Natural gas can be converted to synthesis gas by reacting with H2O (steam reforming, Eq. (1)) and CO2 (dry reforming, Eq. (2)), and H2/CO ratio in the product synthesis gas can be determined by adjusting H2O/CO2 ratio, because stoichiometric H2/CO ratios are 3 for steam reforming (Eq. (1)) and 1 for dry reforming (Eq. (2)) respectively. Combustion of small portion of natural gas is carried out simultaneously (Eq. (3)) to supply reaction energy for highly endothermic reforming reactions (auto-thermal reforming). (1) CH4 +H2O⇄CO+3H2 ΔHr 298K =+205.9kJ/mol (2) CH4 +CO2 ⇄2CO+2H2 ΔHr 298K =+247.1kJ/mol (3) CH4 +2O2 →CO2 +2H2OΔHr 298K =−802.6kJ/mol The produced synthesis gas can be converted to methanol via CO hydrogenation (Eq. (4)). CO2 is produced as a by-product due to the water–gas shift reaction (WGSR, Eq. (5)) and Boudouard reaction (Eq. (6)) of CO. (4) CO+2H2 ⇄CH3OHΔHr 298K =−94.5kJ/mol (5) CO+H2O⇄CO2 +H2 ΔHr 298K =−41.2kJ/mol (6) 2CO⇄CO2 +C(solid)ΔHr 298K =−172.5kJ/mol The synthesis gas usually contains a minor portion of CO2 [7], and it is well known that this small amount of CO2 enhances the rate of methanol formation (“CO 2 -promoted methanol synthesis”) [7,8]. However, because CO is much more active than CO2 and CO concentration is much higher than CO2 concentration, the amount of CO2 generated by water–gas shift reaction (WGSR) of CO is much larger than the amount of CO2 consumed by a hydrogenation. In such a case, the methanol formation from CO2 becomes important in terms of the process efficiency, because it can improve the productivity of methanol and reduce the end-of-pipe CO2 emission. Also, as mentioned above, CO2 hydrogenation to methanol can be applied as a platform technology for the chemical recycling and storage of CO2 [7,9–11]. As a result, CO2 hydrogenation has been studied extensively in last two decades for CO2 and H2 storage technologies as well as for the conventional CO hydrogenation process. CO2 is converted to methanol by catalytic hydrogenation (Eq. (7)). The most undesirable by-product is methane (CH4), which is generated by CO2 methanation reaction (Eq. (8)). Other major competing side reaction is the reverse water–gas shift reaction (rWGSR, Eq. (9)), which occurs via CO2 hydrogenation as well. (7) CO2 +3H2 ⇄CH3OH+H2OΔHr 298K =−49.5kJ/mol (8) CO2 +4H2 ⇄CH4 +2H2OΔHr 298K =−164.7kJ/mol (9) CO2 +H2 ⇄CO+H2OΔHr 298K = +41.2kJ/mol Several previous researches suggested the possible reaction mechanism for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol using computational calculation based on density functional theory (DFT). Proposed mechanisms are classified into two major routes: (1) formate (HCOO) route and (2) rWGSR route via hydrocarboxyl (COOH) intermediate [12–17]. It is reported that HCOO intermediate is more stable than COOH intermediate on Cu(111) surface [12–14], however, the formation of COOH intermediate is promoted by the presence of surface OH group (i.e. under the existence of H2O) [15]. In addition, it is also reported that methanol cannot be produced from formic acid (HCOOH), which implies that HCOO did not contribute to the methanol production [18]. As a result, rWGSR pathway is more reliable as the reaction mechanism for methanol synthesis in the actual reaction condition. The most widely used catalysts are Cu/ZnO-based catalysts in both CO and CO2 hydrogenation to methanol [14]. Recently, it is reported that Cu/CeO2 catalysts also has prominent activity in CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. Graciani et al. reported that the methanol formation rate was about 14 times faster on the CeOx/Cu(111) surface than on the Cu / ZnO ( 000 1 ¯ ) surface, which resulted from the lower activation energy for methanol formation on CeOx/Cu(111) surface (12–13kcal/mol) compared to the activation energy on Cu / ZnO ( 000 1 ¯ ) or ZnO/Cu(111) surfaces (16kcal/mol) [16,19]. This improvement in the activity of the Cu–CeOx surface is majorly attributed to the formation of aforementioned COOH intermediate, while Cu(111) surface stabilizes HCOO intermediate. It implies that CO2 hydrogenation to methanol on Cu–CeOx surface is carried out via CO hydrogenation to methanol, because COOH intermediate is readily dissociated to CO intermediate and consecutively hydrogenated to methanol via formyl (HCO) intermediate [15,16]. However, because CO group can be also detached as carbon monoxide, thus, methanol synthesis and rWGSR share common intermediates (COOH) on Cu-based catalysts: apparent activation energies for methanol synthesis and rWGSR on CeOx/Cu(111) surface are similar, 12 and 11kcal/mol, respectively [16]. It makes the formation of CO unavoidable in CO2 hydrogenation to methanol on the Cu/CeO2 catalysts. The activity of Cu/CeO2 catalysts can be further enhanced by Pd addition. Pd is widely applied as a major catalytic component in CO2 hydrogenation to methanol reaction, because it can efficiently activate the reactants due to its hydrogen spillover effect [20]. H2 spillover ability of Pd improves the methanol formation activity over Cu-based catalysts by enhancing the reducibility of Cu site and suppressing the re-oxidation of Cu surface [21]. This enhanced reducibility of Cu site also promotes the activation of CO2: because the electron-rich metal site tends to interact with carbon atom in CO2 [22], the formation of OCO− group and the hydrogenation to COOH intermediate are promoted by electron transfer from metal sites. As a result, it is reported that the Pd–Cu bimetallic phase is an active species for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol: Pd–Cu supported on amorphous silica exhibited a greater catalytic activity than monometallic Cu/SiO2 or Pd/SiO2 for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol [23]. It is also reported that PdCu(111) is more active in the methanol formation than Cu(111), because the former has a lower activation energy for hydrogenation via the rWGSR pathway [24]. In this study, therefore, a series of CeO2-supported Pd-Cu catalysts, which were synthesized using a deposition-precipitation method, were applied to CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. The activity of catalysts was compared in terms of methanol productivity over the catalyst weight (mmolMeOH/gcat·h) and weight of Cu in catalysts (mmolMeOH/gCu·h). The promoting effects of Pd were investigated by comparing the differences in the activity and properties of Cu/CeO2 and Pd-promoted Cu/CeO2 catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Synthesis of the CeO2 support CeO2 supports were prepared by the precipitation method described in previous studies [25,26]. Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (Aldrich, 99%) was dissolved in 500mL of deionized water, and the temperature was raised to 80°C. After the pH was adjusted to 8 using a 2M solution of Na2CO3 (Aldrich) as a precipitant, the solution was vigorously stirred for 3h at 80°C. Then, the solution was filtered to separate the precipitate, which was consecutively washed with deionized water. The washed precipitate was dried at 80°C for 24h followed by calcination in static air at 600°C for 4h. 2.1.2 Impregnation of Pd and Cu on CeO2 Pd and Cu were impregnated on CeO2 support by a deposition–precipitation method [27,28]. Initially, intended amounts of PdCl2 (Aldrich, 99%) and CuCl2 (Aldrich, 97%) were dissolved in a 0.01M aqueous HCl solution, over which CeO2 (3g) was suspended. The pH of the precursor solution was adjusted to 10 using a 1M Na2CO3 (Aldrich) aqueous solution, and the slurry was vigorously stirred at 70°C for 4h. Afterwards, the slurry was filtered and washed several times with deionized water until no chloride ions were detected (silver nitrate solution was added to detect chloride ions). The resulting solid was dried at 70°C for 24h and calcined in static air at 400°C for 4h. The catalysts were named xPd–yCu/CeO2 according to the weight percentages of Pd (x =0, 0.5, 1, 2) and Cu (y =5, 10, 20) against CeO2 weight in the catalysts. 2.2 Activity test The catalytic activity was tested in a continuous fixed bed reactor packed with 0.2g of catalyst (sieved to 32–106μm). Before the reaction test, the loaded catalyst was pre-reduced under an 8% H2/N2 mixture gas flow (16mL/min) at 0.1MPa and 300°C for 1h. After reduction, the catalyst bed was cooled to room temperature and then purged with the reactant gas (CO2:H2:N2 =22:66:12, where H2/CO2 =3 with N2 as the internal standard). Then, the reactor was pressurized to 3MPa using the reactant gas, and heated to 270°C at a ramp rate of 10°C/min, and maintained for 5h to reach a steady state. The temperature was gradually decreased to the desired temperature (190–270°C), and then the isothermal and isobaric conditions were maintained for 1h for product analysis. The lines between the reactor and the gas chromatograph were heated to 120°C to avoid condensation of methanol. The compositions of the feed and product gases were analyzed by gas chromatography (Younglin YL6500GC), which was equipped with both a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) connected with a Carboxen 1000 column and a flame ionization detector (FID) connected with an HP-Plot Q column. The activity of catalysts is expressed as methanol productivity based on catalyst weight (mmol/gcat·h), Cu weight (mmol/gCu·h) and Pd weight (mmol/gPd·h) using Eqs. (10)–(12). (10) Catalyst weight-based methanol productivity ( mmol / g cat ⋅ h ) = molar flow rate of methanol in the product stream ( mmol/h ) the weight of catalyst ( g ) (11) Cu weight-based methanol productivity ( mmol / g Cu · h ) = molar flow rate of methanol in the product stream ( mmol/h ) the weight of Cu in the catlyst ( g ) (12) Pd weight-based methanol productivity ( mmol/g Pd ⋅ h ) = molar flow rate of methanol in the product stream ( mmol/h ) the weight of Pd in the catalyst ( g ) CO2 conversion and methanol selectivity were calculated based on carbon mole balance using Eqs. (13) and (14) [29]. Methane was not detected, and the only detected byproduct was carbon monoxide. (13) CO 2 conversion ( carbon mol. % ) = 1 − molar flow rate of remaining CO 2 in the product stream ( mol/h ) molar flow rate of CO 2 in the feed stream ( mol/h ) × 100 (14) Methanol selectivity ( carbon mol. % ) = molar flow rate of Methanol in the product stream ( mol/h ) molar flow rate of ( CO+methanol ) in the product stream ( mol/h ) × 100 2.3 Characterization XRD patterns were obtained on an X-ray powder diffractometer (Rigaku D/MAX-2500) operated at 40kV and 100mA with Cu Kα1 irradiation (λ =0.15406nm). The data were collected from 2θ =20–80° at a scanning rate of 2°/min. The domain size of the crystallites was calculated using the Scherrer equation (Eq. (15)). The equation was applied to the major XRD peaks of CeO2 (2θ =28.5°) and Cu (2θ =43.3°) after the peaks were fitted with Lorentzian curves. (15) Scherrer equation t = K λ B cos θ t =the mean size of the crystalline domains (nm), K =dimensionless shape factor (=0.9), λ =wavelength of X-ray (Cu Kα1, 0.15406nm), B =full width at half maximum (FWHM) in radians, θ =Bragg angle. The specific surface area and pore volume of the catalysts were analyzed by N2 adsorption–desorption using a BET instrument, BELSORP-max (BEL Japan, Inc.). The samples were degassed at 4mmHg and 100°C overnight prior to analysis, and the measurements were performed at −196°C. The concentrations of Pd, Cu, and Ce in the prepared catalysts were measured by ICP-AES (Ultima 2, Jobin Yvon Horiba) with support from the Seoul Center of the Korea Basic Science Institute (KBSI). XPS analyses were performed by ex situ way using an AXIS Nova instrument (Kratos) with an Al-Kα X-ray source (1486.6eV). The core-level electron binding energies were calibrated with the reference binding energy of C 1s at 284.6eV. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Methanol productivity for Cu/CeO2 and Pd–Cu/CeO2 catalysts Methanol productivity of Cu/CeO2 catalysts with different Cu loadings (5, 10, 20wt%, without Pd) are presented in Fig. 1 . At first, catalyst weight-based methanol productivity in Fig. 1(a) significantly increased as the Cu loading increased from 5 to 10wt.%, but slightly decreased at a Cu loading of 20wt.% in 190–270°C temperature range. Also, Cu weight-based methanol productivity in 20Cu/CeO2 catalyst is much lower than in both 5Cu/CeO2 and 10Cu/CeO2 catalysts (Fig. 1(b)). Similar result was reported in CO hydrogenation to methanol: space-time yield of methanol (STY, mol/dm3·h) was the highest in 10wt.% Cu/CeO2 among 2–40wt.% Cu/CeO2 catalysts [30]. Authors stated that the decrease in the activity of catalysts with larger Cu amount than 10wt.% was caused by the aggregation of CeO2, but it is more likely to result from the decrease in the dispersion of Cu particles (from H2-TPR, XRD and EXAFS results) in 20–40wt.% Cu/CeO2 catalyst. As a result, methanol productivity was the highest in 10Cu/CeO2 catalyst. The promoting effects of Pd in the activity of catalysts was consecutively investigated: Cu amount was fixed at the optimum composition (10wt.%), and the catalytic activities of xPd–10Cu/CeO2 catalysts (x =0, 0.5, 1, 2) are presented in Fig. 2 . It is clearly observed that Pd addition enhanced methanol productivities (both catalyst weight-based and Cu weight-based), which resulted from the increase in CO2 conversion (Table 1 ): Pd-promoted Cu/CeO2 catalysts achieved the higher CO2 conversion than 10Cu/CeO2 catalyst, although methanol selectivity decreased. 1Pd–10Cu/CeO2 achieved the highest methanol productivities and CO2 conversion among tested catalysts. Because Pd weight-based methanol productivity (displayed in Fig. 3 ) simply decreased as Pd amount increased (0.5Pd–10Cu>1Pd–10Cu>2Pd–10Cu), it implies that promoting effects of Pd was mainly to enhance the activity of Cu sites rather than to provide active sites for CO2 activation. On the other hand, methanol productivity of 1Pd–10Cu/CeO2 was the highest at the reaction temperature of 250°C (Fig. 2). Although CO2 conversion was higher at 270°C (17.8%) than at 250°C (16.1%), the decrease in methanol selectivity (from 26.7% to 23.7%) lowered methanol productivity at 270°C (Table 1). In summary, Pd–Cu/CeO2 catalysts achieved higher methanol productivity than Cu/CeO2 catalysts, and it was the highest in 1Pd–10Cu/CeO2 catalyst. Pd promotion enhanced methanol productivity by increasing CO2 conversion in tested temperature range (190–270°C). It is considered that the major role of Pd was to enhance the activity of Cu sites rather than to provide active sites for CO2 activation, thus, we mainly focused on the influence of Pd addition to active Cu sites in the following sections. 3.2 The influence of Pd promotion to the dispersion and surface concentration of Cu X-ray diffraction patterns of Pd–Cu/CeO2 catalysts after the reaction test is presented in Fig. 4 , and the crystallite sizes of metallic Cu and CeO2 calculated using the Scherrer equation are presented in Table 2 . At first, Pd-related peaks were not observed in the XRD patterns, which might be caused by high dispersion of Pd on the catalyst surface due to strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) between Pd and CeO2 [31–35]. In contrast, the peaks for metallic Cu was clearly observed, but their intensity were differed by the loading amount of Pd on the catalyst. The intensity for metallic Cu peak first decreased as the amount of loaded Pd increased, and this peak disappeared in 1Pd–10Cu/CeO2 (10Cu>0.5Pd–10Cu>1Pd-10Cu). This result implies that the Cu dispersion on the catalyst surface was enhanced by Pd addition and was the highest with 1wt.% of Pd (1Pd–10Cu/CeO2), because Pd promotion reduced the crystallite of metallic Cu (Table 2). This increase of Cu dispersion by Pd addition was also observed in Pd–Cu/CeO2 catalysts applied in oxygen-enhanced water gas shift reaction (oWGSR): Kugai et al. stated that the interaction between Pd and Cu causes the decrease in CuCu bond distance due to the strong electronic perturbation, and Cu species were more dispersed with the presence of Pd [36]. Thus, it is considered that the aggregation of Cu particles was suppressed due to the interaction with Pd, which was highly dispersed on CeO2 support. On the other hand, the peak for metallic Cu re-appeared in 2Pd–10Cu/CeO2 catalyst (Fig. 4), which indicates that the Cu dispersion in 2Pd–10Cu/CeO2 was lower than that in 1Pd–10Cu/CeO2. This decrease of Cu dispersion might be caused by the decrease in the surface area and pore volume of catalyst due to the largest amount of loaded metals: both BET specific surface area and mean pore volume of 2Pd–10Cu/CeO2 were the lowest among tested catalysts (Table 3 ). The bulk and surface concentrations of Cu and Pd in Pd–Cu/CeO2 catalysts after the reaction test are presented in Table 4 , which are expressed in terms of weight fraction (wt.%). Both Cu and Pd concentrations on the surface were higher than bulk concentrations in all catalysts, because Cu and Pd were impregnated on the surface of CeO2 by the deposition-precipitation method (see Section 2.1.2). It is remarkable that the surface Cu concentration in Pd-promoted Cu/CeO2 catalysts (28.6–38.5wt.%) were much higher than in 10Cu/CeO2 catalyst (12.7wt.%), and increased as the loaded Pd amount increased without any noticeable change in bulk concentration. It implies that Pd promotion made Cu remain on the surface of CeO2 by the aforementioned interaction between Pd and Cu. In addition, it is well known that reducible oxide supports such as CeO2 and TiO2 are able to migrate onto the metal surface and to block the active sites under reducible atmosphere [37–39]. It is considered that this migration of CeO2 onto active Cu sites during reduction and reaction was suppressed by Pd promotion, because CeO2 encapsulation in Pd/CeO2 occurs at higher temperature above 600°C [37]. Thus, Pd not only hold Cu to remain on the surface by the Pd-Cu interaction, but also suppressed the encapsulation by CeO2, which resulted in the higher surface Cu concentration in Pd–Cu/CeO2 catalysts. On the other hand, the surface concentration of Cu in 2Pd–10Cu/CeO2 catalyst (38.4wt.%) did not increase compared to the concentration in 1Pd–10Cu/CeO2 catalyst (38.5wt.%) due to the increase in the surface concentration of Pd (from 3.6wt.% to 9.6wt.%). In summary, Pd promotion enhanced the dispersion and surface concentration of Cu in Pd–Cu/CeO2 catalysts. The dispersion of Cu particles and the surface Cu concentration increased as the amount of loaded Pd increased, but they were the highest in 1Pd–10Cu/CeO2. Because CO2 hydrogenation activity to methanol increases as the exposed Cu surface area increases [29], as a result, Pd promotion enhanced methanol productivity by increasing the dispersion and surface concentration of Cu in Pd–Cu/CeO2 catalysts, which were the highest in 1Pd–10Cu/CeO2 catalyst. 3.3 The influence of Pd promotion to the electron structure of active Cu sites XPS spectra for Cu 2p and Pd 3d electrons are presented in Fig. 5 . First, it is clear observed that the peaks for Cu 2p electrons in Pd–Cu/CeO2 catalysts appeared at relatively lower binding energy than the peaks in 10Cu/CeO2 catalyst (Fig. 5(a)), i.e. Cu sites in Pd–Cu/CeO2 catalysts were more electron-rich than in 10Cu/CeO2 catalyst. It was reported that Cu could be stabilized in a more reduced state because Pd donates electrons to Cu [40]. The occurrence of this donation of electrons from Pd can be verified by comparing XPS spectra for 1Pd–10Cu/CeO2 and 2Pd–10Cu/CeO2 catalysts: Cu 2p electrons in 1Pd–10Cu/CeO2 had lower binding energies (Fig. 5(a)), while the binding energy for Pd 3d electrons was lower in 2Pd–10Cu/CeO2 (Fig. 5(b)). Thus, Pd promotion generated more electron-rich Cu site by electron transfer. However, the binding energy for Cu 2p electrons did not simply decrease as the amount of Pd increased, and was the highest in 1Pd–10Cu/CeO2. It might result from the decrease of contact area between Cu and Pd, which hinders the electron transfer, due to the decrease of surface area and pore volume in 2Pd–10Cu/CeO2 catalyst (Table 3). On the other hand, although Pd existed as almost fully oxidized state in 0.5Pd–10Cu/CeO2 catalyst (Fig. 5(b)), the binding energy of Cu 2p electrons in 0.5Pd–10Cu/CeO2 catalyst was higher than the binding energy in 1Pd–10Cu/CeO2 catalyst (Fig. 5(a)) due to the less amount of electron source (0.5wt.% Pd). As a result, because Cu in a reduced state is more active for methanol formation than in the oxidized states [21,41], methanol productivity was the highest in 1Pd–10Cu/CeO2 catalyst which possessed the most electron-rich Cu sites. 3.4 The influence of Pd promotion to the surface of CeO2 support XPS spectra for Ce 3d electrons are presented in Fig. 6 . Because the electron structure of Ce 3d orbitals is severely influenced by the hybridization of Ce 4f orbitals with O 2p valence band, Ce 3d electrons have several energy levels and Ce 3d spectra can be deconvoluted into 10 peaks: v, v 0, v′, v″, v‴ for 3d5/2 and u, u 0, u′, u″, u‴ for 3d3/2 [42,43]. For 3d5/2, v 0 and v’ peaks can be assigned to Ce2O3 (Ce3+), while v, v″ and v‴ peaks can be attributed to CeO2 (Ce4+). In Fig. 6, it is observed that the surface of CeO2 support was slightly reduced, although the reduction of bulk CeO2 was not observed in XRD (Fig. 4). Because v 0 peak did not appeared in XPS spectra for 10Cu/CeO2 catalyst, therefore, Pd addition promoted the reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+ on the surface. In addition, the peak with much lower binding energy (peak 1 in Fig. 6) appeared in 3d5/2 spectra for 1Pd–10Cu/CeO2 catalyst, which was not identified in previous researches. Although the origin of this peak is not clear, it is certain that the surface of CeO2 support with 1wt.% of Pd was in a more reduced state among tested Pd–Cu/CeO2 catalysts. It is well known that this partial reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+ generates a surface defect called oxygen vacancy, which activates and dissociates CO2 into adsorbed CO groups [44]. As a result, it is considered that this highest Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio in 1Pd–10Cu/CeO2 catalyst generated more oxygen-vacant sites, which resulted in the highest CO2 conversion among tested catalysts. Furthermore, this highest Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio in 1Pd–10Cu/CeO2 catalyst could be another reason for the highest dispersion of Cu in 1Pd–10Cu/CeO2 catalyst, because Cu is stabilized at defect sites in CeOx resulting in better dispersion of Cu [45]. 4 Conclusion In this work, Cu/CeO2 and Pd–Cu/CeO2 catalysts were applied in CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. It is supposed that Pd was highly dispersed on the surface of CeO2 support, and the interaction between highly-dispersed Pd and Cu lead to the increase in the dispersion of Cu particles and the surface concentration of Cu. Pd promotion also generated more reduced Cu site and CeO2 surface by donating electrons to Cu and CeO2. These promoting effects of Pd were the highest in 1Pd–10Cu/CeO2 catalyst, because further increase in the amount of loaded Pd (2wt.%) lowered the textural properties of catalyst (pore volume, surface area). In consequence, CO2 conversion and methanol productivity were enhanced in Pd-promoted Cu/CeO2 catalysts and the highest in 1Pd–10Cu/CeO2 catalyst. coredata.dc:description: CO2 hydrogenation to methanol receives great attention recently not only in conventional CO hydrogenation process but also in CO2 and H2 storage technologies. CO2 can be converted to methanol by catalytic hydrogenation, and it is supposed that CO2 is hydrogenated to methanol via hydrocarboxyl (COOH) intermediate (rWGSR route) rather than formate (HCOO) intermediate. It was reported that CeOx/Cu(111) surface stabilizes COOH intermediate, which consecutively results in lower activation energy for methanol formation than on Cu(111) and Cu / ZnO ( 000 1 ¯ ) surfaces. The activity of Cu/CeO2 catalysts can be further enhanced by Pd addition, because it can enhance reducibility of Cu site. In this study, therefore, Cu/CeO2 and Pd–Cu/CeO2 catalysts were applied to CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. Pd-promoted Cu/CeO2 catalysts achieved higher methanol productivity than Cu/CeO2 catalyst due to the increase in CO2 conversion. Because methanol productivity over Pd weight (mmolMeOH/gPd·h) simply decreased as the amount of Pd increased, it is considered that the enhanced activity of Pd–Cu/CeO2 catalysts mainly resulted from the increase in the reactivity of active Cu sites. The dispersion and surface concentration of Cu increased due to the interaction with highly-dispersed Pd, and Cu sites were more reduced by Pd promotion due to electron donation from Pd. Pd promotion also generated more reduced CeO2 surface. These promoting effects of Pd was the highest in the catalyst containing 1wt.% Pd (1Pd–10Cu/CeO2), because further increase in the amount of loaded Pd lowered the textural properties of catalyst. As a result, methanol productivity was enhanced in Pd-promoted Cu/CeO2 catalysts and the highest in 1Pd–10Cu/CeO2 catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol over Pd–Cu/CeO2 catalysts
